content:
Let SSS be a set, regarded as discrete category.

Is there any hope to describe explicitly the free category with finite limits on SSS? Other than when SSS is a singleton (it's the opposite of finite sets and functions), I can't see how.
Shouldn't this just be a sum of copies of Setop\bf Set^{op}Setop? Building the free finite-limit category ought to be a left adjoint, hence preserve the coproduct.
Sum in finite-limit categories (e.g., shared terminal object).
It should be the opposite of (finite sets equipped with a map to S).
If S is finite then it's also the opposite of (S-indexed families of finite sets).

To put it another way, the free finite limit completion of a discrete category is the free finite product completion of a discrete category, because there are no nontrivial nondiscrete limits in a discrete category.
Mmh, I find both arguments convincing, but somehow I'm having trouble proving the universal property..

I really want to believe your conjecture but I can't figure out how to make it precise: let F:S→AF : S \to {\cal A}F:S→A be a functor, i.e. a SSS-family of objects of a category with finite limits.

Now, there is an obvious unit map S→(Fin/S)opS\to (Fin/S)^{op}S→(Fin/S)op sending sss to s:{∗}→Ss:\{*\}\to Ss:{∗}→S.

Trying to extend FFF to a Fˉ\bar FFˉ along the above candidate unit,

  1. On one side, in order for Fˉ\bar FFˉ to act like FFF on objects of the form s:{∗}→Ss : \{*\}\to Ss:{∗}→S, one would like to define Fˉ(A→S)=∏{s∣As≠∅}Fs\bar F (A\to S)=\prod_{\{s\mid A_s\ne\emptyset\}}FsFˉ(A→S)=∏{s∣As​=∅}​Fs
  2. On the other hand, this functor is clearly not product preserving (it doesn't preserve the terminal object, i.e. the identity of SSS --I am thinking SSS finite)
The terminal object is the empty set mapping to S.
ah but the domain is the opposite of (Fin/S)(Fin/S)(Fin/S). Then the terminal object is not 1_S
indeed, indeed
Probably easier to just replace limits by colimits throughout
Ok now I am convinced!

Spencer Breiner said:

Shouldn't this just be a sum of copies of Setop\mathsf {Set^{op}}Setop? Building the free finite-limit category ought to be a left adjoint, hence preserve the coproduct.

By the way, this is the free category with all small limits on a set. The free category with finite limits on a set SSS should be a sum of SSS copies of FinSetop\mathsf {FinSet^{op}}FinSetop, I believe.
But this should be (FinSet/S)op(\mathsf{FinSet}/S)^{\mathsf{op}}(FinSet/S)op, as Reid said - that's a bit more concrete.
And as Nathaniel pointed out, this is also the free category with finite products on SSS.
(I'm just trying to put all this nice stuff in one place.)

Now that I think about it, why the extension of FFF preserves products? Given a coproduct in Fin/SFin/SFin/S, i.e. the map A⊔B→SA\sqcup B\to SA⊔B→S, why is Fˉ[A⊔B↓S]≅F[A↓S]×Fˉ[B↓S]\bar F\left[\begin{smallmatrix}A\sqcup B \\\downarrow\\ S\end{smallmatrix}\right]\cong F\left[\begin{smallmatrix}A \\\downarrow\\ S\end{smallmatrix}\right]\times\bar F\left[\begin{smallmatrix} B \\\downarrow\\ S\end{smallmatrix}\right]Fˉ[A⊔B↓S​]≅F[A↓S​]×Fˉ[B↓S​], if Fˉ\bar FFˉ sends a:A→Sa : A\to Sa:A→S to the product ∏s∈im(a)Fs\prod_{s\in im(a)} Fs∏s∈im(a)​Fs?

There's a funny mix of products and coproducts in your question. I find it easier to work only with coproducts until the very last minute.

I claim the free category with finite colimits on a set SSS is FinSet/S\mathsf{FinSet}/SFinSet/S. Given a functor F:S→AF: S \to \mathsf{A}F:S→A where AAA has finite colimits we want to extend FFF to a finite-colimit-preserving functor F‾:FinSet/S→A\overline{F} : \mathsf{FinSet}/S \to \mathsf{A}F:FinSet/S→A.

Here's how F‾\overline{F}F works: it sends f:A→Sf: A \to Sf:A→S to

∑x∈AF(f(x))\sum_{x \in A} F(f(x)) ∑x∈A​F(f(x))

The coproduct in FinSet/S\mathsf{FinSet}/SFinSet/S of f:A→Sf: A \to Sf:A→S and g:B→Sg: B \to Sg:B→S is ⟨f,g⟩:A⊔B→S\langle f, g \rangle: A \sqcup B \to S⟨f,g⟩:A⊔B→S. Here ⟨f,g⟩ \langle f, g \rangle⟨f,g⟩ is my notation for the map that equals fff on AAA and ggg on BBB.

So, F‾\overline{F}F sends the coproduct of f:A→Sf: A \to Sf:A→S and g:B→Sg: B \to Sg:B→S to

∑x∈A⊔BF(⟨f,g⟩(x))=∑x∈AF(f(x))+∑x∈BF(g(x))\sum_{x \in A \sqcup B} F(\langle f, g \rangle (x)) = \sum_{x \in A } F(f(x)) + \sum_{x \in B} F(g(x)) ∑x∈A⊔B​F(⟨f,g⟩(x))=∑x∈A​F(f(x))+∑x∈B​F(g(x))

So F‾\overline{F}F preserves binary coproducts.

Once we finish showing that FinSet/S\mathsf{FinSet}/SFinSet/S is the free category with finite colimits on SSS, we can instantly conclude that (FinSet/S)op(\mathsf{FinSet}/S)^{\text{op}}(FinSet/S)op is the free category with finite limits on SSS.

Spencer Breiner said:

Shouldn't this just be a sum of copies of Setop\bf Set^{op}Setop? Building the free finite-limit category ought to be a left adjoint, hence preserve the coproduct.

Right, but the left adjoint goes to categories with finite limits, hence the free finite-limit category on SSS should be a coproduct of SSS copies of Setop\mathbf{Set}^{\mathit{op}}Setop in the (large) category of finite-limit categories. And this coproduct is not preserved by the forgetful functor to CAT\mathbf{CAT}CAT, is it?

John Baez said:

There's a funny mix of products and coproducts in your question. I find it easier to work only with coproducts until the very last minute.

I claim the free category with finite colimits on a set SSS is FinSet/S\mathsf{FinSet}/SFinSet/S. Given a functor F:S→AF: S \to \mathsf{A}F:S→A where AAA has finite colimits we want to extend FFF to a finite-colimit-preserving functor F‾:FinSet/S→A\overline{F} : \mathsf{FinSet}/S \to \mathsf{A}F:FinSet/S→A.

Here's how F‾\overline{F}F works: it sends f:A→Sf: A \to Sf:A→S to

∑x∈AF(f(x))\sum_{x \in A} F(f(x)) ∑x∈A​F(f(x))

The coproduct in FinSet/S\mathsf{FinSet}/SFinSet/S of f:A→Sf: A \to Sf:A→S and g:B→Sg: B \to Sg:B→S is ⟨f,g⟩:A⊔B→S\langle f, g \rangle: A \sqcup B \to S⟨f,g⟩:A⊔B→S. Here ⟨f,g⟩ \langle f, g \rangle⟨f,g⟩ is my notation for the map that equals fff on AAA and ggg on BBB.

So, F‾\overline{F}F sends the coproduct of f:A→Sf: A \to Sf:A→S and g:B→Sg: B \to Sg:B→S to

∑x∈A⊔BF(⟨f,g⟩(x))=∑x∈AF(f(x))+∑x∈BF(g(x))\sum_{x \in A \sqcup B} F(\langle f, g \rangle (x)) = \sum_{x \in A } F(f(x)) + \sum_{x \in B} F(g(x)) ∑x∈A⊔B​F(⟨f,g⟩(x))=∑x∈A​F(f(x))+∑x∈B​F(g(x))

So F‾\overline{F}F preserves binary coproducts.

Yes, I just got the wrong definition of Fˉ\bar FFˉ, silly mistake.
